Fix Gradle caching regression introduced in 27.3.8.

In Java plugins, Gradle cannot generate a consistent hash key for doFirst
and doLast actions attached to tasks, and so those tasks won't particpate
in up-to-date checking or caching.

In this commit, we wrap the doFirst and doLast actions for all tasks with
a CacheableAction class that Gradle will use to produce a consistent
cache key.

Fix a race condition bug in CompositeWriter.

Race condition happens when the end of a entity stream in the composite
writer co-incides with wh.remaining() becoming zero.

Since the entity stream has reached the end, it will trigger onDone,
which in turn will trigger the initializtion of the next stream through
onInit.

Now, if the network stream invokes onWritePossibe (since previous
wh.remaining() returned zero), the execution in onWritePossible and
onInit will go in parallel, causing the incorrect handling of
_outstanding.

[pegasus]:[pegasus] R2 netty pipeline refactoring

Upgraded to Netty 4.1.34

Refactored namespace structures under the r2-netty module. New classes and some reused classes are added/moved to com.linkedin.r2.netty namespace. Following are the major folder under the new refactored namespace 'com.linkedin.r2.netty namespace'
- callback: internal implementation of callback
- client: public interface for creating the client
- common: utility classes
- entitystream: R2 entity stream implementation of Read and Writer
- handler: Netty handler implementations shared between HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2, stream and non-stream, client and server (not in this RB)

See detailed pipeline documentation in HttpChannelInitializer and Http2ChannelInitializer. The two classes describe steps of how the pipelines are setup.

The HttpNettyClient class is the new common TransportClient implementation for both HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2, stream and non-stream. The following is some major changes.
- callbackExecutor can no longer be null
- user callback executed in correct thread during error

Exposed a boolean flag in HttpClientFactory to switch between new and old Netty pipeline implementation. Will be exposed through Offspring. We will remove these switches and old Netty pipeline code once we have enough confidence on the new Netty Pipeline.

When Netty makes outbound StreamRequest calls, the EntityStreams reader call backs execution is not guranteed to  preserve the original order intended by the data producer (writer) if the writer started producing data on a differetnt thread than the one initiated by the reader. This is due to the very nature of single threaded Netty eventloop. Netty runs all the outbound channel writes immediately if the call back thread is eventloop executer. But if the call back thread is user thread, netty queues call back for later execution and hence breaking the call back order by giving some call backs priority and others not. More details on this issue can be found @
jira item SI-11732. This rb creates a decorated reader (OrderedEntityStreamReader) and it make sure that all the write requests are queued to the eventloop to presere the call back order. This make sure that outbound calls behaviour cannot be changed by user code sitting in the EntityStreams data producing side

[pegasus][SI-10795] Updating the version in preparation for release

[pegasus][SI-10795] R2 REST Clients was providing HTTP/2 style multiple line cookie header format during HTTP/1.1 requests. These multiple line cookie header formats are not in complient with RFC 6265 during HTTP/1.1 requests. Long story short - As per RFC 6265, there should only have one Cookie Header during HTTP/1.1 requests. When multiple cookies needs to be sent to the server, those cookies should be sent as part of a single cookie header with the format Cookie=Cookie1Name=Cookie1Value;Cookie2Name=Cookie2Value;....CoookieNName=CookieNValue. This commits takes care of correctly encoding the list of Cookies in to a single string cookie format as mentioned above. This make sure that all the downstream HTTP/1.1 calls are in compliance with RFC 6265

In the http2 specification referenced below, is suggested that the upgrade request clients use OPTIONS request for path “*” or a HEAD request for “/”. We are currently using the path of the actual user request that will be made after the upgrade (_path variable).

Therefore in the current implementation, if the user makes a request to /echo123, the server would first receive an upgrade OPTION request to /echo123, and then the actual user request (GET/POST/OPTIONS/DELETE, etc..) to /echo123.
After applying the change, the server will first receive an OPTION request to *, and then the actual user request to /echo123

Since we use R2 http2 only with Rest.li clients that implement the OPTIONS request, and we know the behavior of such a path, this didn't trigger any unwanted behaviors.
In a more generic use case (R2 client to non rest.li resources), this could have unintended consequences

Furthermore this change is needed to make the handshake before the first request comes in. In fact, before the first request comes in, we don't know the path.

Reference:
https://http2.github.io/faq/#can-i-implement-http2-without-implementing-http11

Improved flexibility and configurability

Improved flexibility and configurability of GenerateDataTemplateTask task
needed for Play on Gradle / voyager-api, while keeping backwards compatibility.

### Motivation

While working on Play on Gradle support for voyager-api
we found it necessary to convert GenerateDataTemplateTask to JavaExec task.
Doing so offers more configurability and flexibility
because we can leverage JavaExec task API to tweak the behavior of the task.
For example, clients can tweak jvm args of the task
and use 'li-pathing-jar' plugin to tackle command line arg limit for classpath.

### Implementation

1. In constructor we additionally create a 'config task' that is responsible for configuring the instance of GenerateDataTemplateTask.
See the code comment that describes the details.
2. Kept backwards binary compatibility of all the public properties of the task.
Type hierarchy is changed due to the change of the base class
but it should not be problematic because clients do not extend GenerateDataTemplateTask class but only refer to the type / task or create instances.
3. Started using Groovy's @CompileStatic to catch problems earlier
during compilation time. It also makes code execution faster.
4. Tested by running the build and inspecting the behavior of the config task and the target task.

indicate to external developers if a method supported paging.

The solution was to look at method parameters of finder and get_all
methods and if it contained PagingContextParam, then add an attribute to
the idl to indicate the method supported paging.
This change has the side effect of generating modified idls for any
existing resource that had a get_all or finder method with paging. Hence
it was decided to make this change a major version so current users do
not see un-intended changes to rest specs.

pagingSupported field during the checks.
  - Adding paging support to existing method is backward compatible.

servers pagination support and removing it can cause undesired
side-effects.

Add a d2 delay test framework

This framework combines TrackerClients with the LoadBalancer so that we can easily
simulate the delays of the requests and observe/debug the loadBalancer behavior.

Components:

. ClockedExecutor: running in a single thread to schedule/run tasks. It also
  implemented the Clock interface to provide the simulated clock function.

. DelayClient: implements the TransportClient interface. For each request
  sent to DelayClient, it schedule a delayed task in ClockedExecutor for the
  response.

. RequestScheduler: A repeatable task running in ClockedExecutor (currently a simple
  lamda function, need to enhance to support more complicated scenarios), sending
  requests with different delays.

BTW, If we replace the simulated executor with a real ServiceExecutor, we can start a
bunch of concurrent requests. That should be able to stress the d2 system and help
to test/debug race issues (if there is any).

Improve memory and performance efficiency for LoadBalancerState

Currently when DegraderLoadBalancerStrategy updates state, it always builds up
a new consistent hashing ring with thousands of new points, therefore not most
efficient. This change tries to address this problem in two ways:

1. Reuse all the points when possible. A separate ring factory keeps all the
   generated points around, and only create new ones when needed. This can
   reduce the garbage generating and avoid the computational intensive hashing
   calculation. The original idea came from Diego Buthay in RB 570649.

2. Replace the TreeSet + arrays of objects with ArrayList to achieve the same
   performance with less memory consumption therefore GC friendly.

Fix two possible race conditions for d2 trackerclient choosing.

1. New clusterGenerationID might not be picked up immediately when state update
   is skipped due to tryLock() failure. This can cause trackerClient list
   inconsistent with the hash ring.

   Solution: instead of moving tryLock() to lock(), which could impact the
   performance, decision has been made to iterate through the hashring again
   for available trackerClient when the inconsistency happens.

2. There is a gap between state update checking and picking up the consistent
   hash ring. Any update in the hash ring within this gap can cause inconsistency.

   Solution: grab the hash ring as soon as possible.

Fix HttpClientFactory.shutdown() tying up executor.

When invoking shutdown() with a timeout, the factory schedules a task
to complete the shutdown after the timeout expires.  In case the
shutdown completes sooner, as it usually does, this leaves the
executor in a state that it cannot be shutdown cleanly, since it still
has the delayed task in its work queue until the delay elapses.

The fix is to cancel the delayed task as soon as the shutdown is
finished.

Incidentally, this also ensures that the shutdown finish procedure
itself never happens more than once.

to encode.  This change was made primarily to simplify picking the right header.  There's no
point in trying to figure out the right content-type header to send back if there isn't
actually any content to send.
Accept-Type headers can now be sent with requests.  The default client won't send Accept-Type
headers (same as the old code), but users can use the new RestClient constructor to create a
client that will send Accept-Type headers.  Right now there are four basic options for
Accept-Type headers:
- no header: server will send back result as application/json.  This is required for backwards
compatibility.
- application/json highest quality in header: server will send back result as application/json
- application/x-pson highest quality in header: server will send back result as
application/x-pson.  If the server code is old, result will be sent back as application/json
- */* highest quality in header: for now, server will send back result as application/json, if

formats that are explicitly mentioned in the header, even when they are lower quality than */*

Make ByteString.toString() to return a summary instead of the whole
array as an Avro string.

Now, ByteString.toString() returns a summary that includes at most the
first and last four bytes (as hex values) and the total length.  Since
we don't know what character encoding is used, or even whether the
bytes represent an encoded string, we should not assume any encoding
when toString() is called.  If the user wants to interpret the
ByteString as an encoded character string, he should call one of the
other methods that specifies an encoding.  Also, including the whole
ByteString in the toString() is not optimal since the toString() may
end up in log files.

Thread1                             Thread2
Get a transport client

                                    Shutdown old client to refresh transport clients
Use transport client (receive an error)
